Each of the five Judges comprising the Constitution Bench of the Court rendered his separate opinion without reference to the facts mainly on the following two questions: ( 1) How to identify the backward classes for the purposes of reservations and (2) What should be permissible extent of the reservations. Per Chandrachud, C. J. The reservations in employment and education in favour of Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes should continue as it is for another period of 15 years. Thereafter, the test of economic backwardness ought to be made applicable to them so that the privileged section amongst them may not monopolise preferential benefits for an indefinite period of time. For identilying the other backward classes for the purposes of reservations, the following two tests should be conjwictively applied: (,) They should be comparable to the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes in the matter of backwardness; and (ii) they should satisfy the means test i.e. the test of backwardness such as the Seate Government may lay down in the context of prevailing economic conditions. The policy of reservation in employment, education and legislative institutions should be reviewed every five years or so. (Para 2) Per Desai, J. ( l) The root cause of social and educational backwardness lies in economic backwardness. So the economic criterion should be applied to identify social and educational backwardness for the purpose of compensatory discrimination or affirmative action. To this may be added some relevant criteria such as the secular character of the group, its opportunity for earning livelihood etc. but by and large economic backwardness must be the loadstar. For reservation in favour of Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes also the economic criterion is worth applying by refusing preferred treatment to those amongst them who have already benefited by it and improved their position. The generality and the totality of the situation have to be seen. (Para 38) The courts are not necessarily the most competent to identify the backward classes or to lay down guide-lines for their identification except in broad and very general way. (Para 38) While dealing with the connected provisions of the Constitution, the Court should not apply the ordinary rules of statutory interpretation to interpret constitutional instruments which are sui generis and which deal with situations of significance and consequence. The Court should remember that it is expounding a Constitution born in the mid-twentieth century, but of an anti-imperialist struggle, influenced by constitutional instruments, events and revolutions elsewhere, in search of a better world, and wedded to the idea of justice, economic, social and political to all. Such a Constitution must be given a generous interpretation so as to give all its citizens the full measure of justice promised by it. The expositors of the Constitution are to concern themselves less with mere words and arrangement of words than with the philosophy and the pervading "spirit and sense" of the Constitution, so elaborately exposed for our guidance in the Directive Principles of State Policy and other provisions of the Constitution. (Para 51) ''The backward classes of citizens" referred to in Article 16(4) despite the short description, are the same as "the socially and educationally back- ward classes of citizens and the Scheduled Castes and the Scheduled Tribes", so fully described in Article 15(4). (Para 49) The question of 1 eservation cannot be viewed as the conflict between the 'meritarian' principle and the compensatory principle. The real conflict is between the class of people who have never been poor or who have already moved out of poverty, illiteracy and backwardness and those who are still poor, illiterate and backward. Looking at the question of 'backwardness', whether f1001 the angle of class, status or power, economic factor is at the bottom of it all and attainment of economic equality is the final and the only i.olution to the besetting problems. Therefore, poverty is the primary test to identify the social and educational backwardness. But class poverty, Pot individual poverty, should b<> the real test. Despite individual exceptions, it may be possible and easy to identify social back- wardness with reference to caste, residence, occupation or some other dominant feature. If they reflect poverty which is the primary source of social and educational backwardness, they must be recognised for what they are along with other less primary sources. Other ancillary tests are the way of life, the standard of living, the place in the social hierarchy, the customs which they honour and observe, the rituals which they fear and practise, the habits 10 which they adapt and conform, the festivals which they enjoy and celebrate and even the gods that they revere and worship. These are enlightening elements in recognising their social gradation and backwardness. However, there is no point in attempting to determine the social backwardness of other classes by applying the test of nearne~s to the conditions of rxistence of the Scheduled Castes. (Para 85) While operating Articles 15(4) and 16(4) the State's objective of bringing about and maintaining social justice must be achieved reasonably having regard to the interests of all. It is primarily the duty and function of the State to inject moderation into the decisions taken under Articles 15(4) and 16(4). (Para 86) (2) The extent of reservation under Articles 15(4) and 16(4) must necessarily vary from State to State and from region to region within a State, depending upon the conditions prevailing in a particular State or region, of the backward classes. The adequacy or otherwise of representation of the back- ward classes in the services has to be determined with reference to the percen- tage of that class in the population and the total strength of the service as a whole. The representation does not have to exactly correspond to the percentage of that class in the population; it just has to be adequate. Moreover, in the case of services the extent of representation had to be cc,nsidered by taking into account the number of members of that class in the service, whether they are holding reserved or unreserved posts. The State should give due importance and effect to the dual constitutional mandates of maintenance of efficiency and the equality of opportunity for all persons. The nature and extent of reservations must be rational and reasonable. It may be, and often is, difficult for the court to draw the line in advance which the State ought not to cross, but it is never difficult for the court to know that an invasion across the border, however ill-defined, has taken place. (Paras 85 and 87) However, the doctrine of protective discrimination embodied in Articles 15(4) and 16(4) and the mandate of Article 29(2) cannot be stretched beyond a particular limit. In services or posts under the Union or States where professional, technological, scientific or other special skill is called for, there can be no room for reservation of posts; merit alone must be the sole and decisive consideration for appointments. (Para 88) The Central Government should consider the feasibility of appointing a permanent National Commission for backward classes which must constantly carry out sociological and economic study from State to State and from region to region within a State. The framers of the Constitution by enacting Article 340 clearly envisaged the setting up of such a high-powered National Commission for backward classes at the Centre. These problems can never be resolved through litigation in the courts. (Para 87) Per V,nkataramiah, J. The meaning of backward classes has to be deduced having regard to the other words preceding it. It is a rule of statutory construction that where there are general words following particular and specific words, the general words must be confined to things of the same kind as those specified. It is true that the rule of ejusdem generis or noscitur a sociis cannot be carried too far. But it is reasonable to apply that rule where the specific words refer to a distinct genus or category. Part XVI was not enacted for the purpose of alleviat- ing the conditions of poorer classes as such which was taken care of by the provisions of Part IV of the Constitution and in particular by Article 46 and by Articles 14, 15 (I) and 16( I) which permitted classification of persons on economic grounds for special treatment in order to ensure equality of opportunity to all persons. While relief may be given in cases of physical disability, poverty, place of habitation, the fact of belonging to a freedom fighter's family or to the family of a member of the armed forces under Articles 14, 15(1) and 16(1) by adopting a rational principle of classification, Articles 15(4) and 16(4) cannot be applied to them. Articles 15(4) and 16(4) are intended for the benefit of those who belong to castes/communities which are" traditionally disfavoured and which have suffered societal discrimination" in the past. It is, therefore, difficult to hold that persons who are backward merely on account of poverty which is traceable to economic reasons can also be considered as backward classes for purposes of Article 16(4) and Part XVI of the Constitution.
